Introduction of NiSO4 to Ni/SiO2 catalyst in hydrogenation of furfuryl alcohol: Tailoring metallic nickel sites to switch major product from tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol to cyclopentanone Xiaoqing Zhang Investigation Methodology Formal analysis Writing – original draft a Yuewen Shao Investigation Data curation a Kai Sun Investigation a Mengjiao Fan Data curation Supervision a Shu Zhang Validation Supervision b Xun Hu Supervision Funding acquisition Writing – review & editing a ⁎ a School of Material Science and Engineering, University of Jinan, Jinan 250022, PR China School of Material Science and Engineering University of Jinan Jinan 250022 PR China aSchool of Material Science and Engineering, University of Jinan, Jinan 250022, PR China b School of New Energy Science and Engineering, Nanjing Forestry University, Nanjing, 210037, PR China School of New Energy Science and Engineering, Nanjing Forestry University Nanjing 210037 PR China bSchool of New Energy Science and Engineering, Nanjing Forestry University, Nanjing, 210037, PR China ⁎ Corresponding author. Nickel-based catalysts are widely used in hydrogenation of varied types of organics. However, the nickel catalyst, like Ni/SiO2, lacks selectivity for hydrogenation of C=C and C=O. This is undesirable in some scenarios, such as conversion of biomass-derived furfuryl alcohol (FA) to cyclopentanone (CPO), a fine chemical, in which the C=C in furan ring of FA needs to be retained. In this study, introduction of sulfur species to Ni/SiO2 catalyst via loading NiSO4 was adopted to inhibit hydrogenation of furan ring in FA, aiming to achieve conversion of FA to CPO via ring-opening route. The results indicated that NiSO4 was reduced to NixSy, which further reacted with metallic Ni, forming Ni3S2 species and introducing the acidic sites with high-strength. The co-existence of NixSy and metallic Ni species effectively hindered hydrogenation of furan ring in FA, reducing tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol (THFA) yield from 97% over Ni/SiO2 to 0 over the NiSx/SiO2 catalysts and shifting the major product to CPO. Nonetheless, the enhanced acidic sites along with the introduction of NiSO4 catalyzed polymerization of reaction intermediates, competing with the production of CPO. The acidic sites, however, facilitated hydrogenolysis of vanillyl alcohol to selectively produce (yield: 94.3%) in hydrogenation of vanillin. Characterization of hydrogenation of FA with in-situ Diffuse Reflectance Infrared Fourier Transform Spectroscopy (DRIFTS) technique suggested the oxygen-containing functionalities in FA, instead of furan ring, could strongly adsorb on the NiS10/SiO2 catalyst, enhancing rearrangement reaction to form CPO while suppressing hydrogenation of the furan ring. Graphical abstract Selective conversion of furfuryl alcohol to cyclopentanone was achieved over the Ni/SiO2 catalyst with Ni3S2 particles. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Furfuryl alcohol Tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol Cyclopentanone Ni-based catalysts Hydrogenation Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Cyclopentanone (CPO) is a versatile chemical intermediate that can be used to synthesize biologically active compounds, pharmaceutical intermediates, adhesives, fragrance chemicals, insecticides and herbicides, and synthetic resins [1,2]. CPO is traditionally synthesized via the ketonic decarboxylation of adipic acid [3,4], or catalytic cyclization of 1,6-hexanediol [5–7], followed by hydrogenation. However, the depleting petroleum resources has induced great interest in the production of CPO from furfural or furfuryl alcohol (FA), the platform molecules from hydrolysis or pyrolysis of biomass [8–10], as such a reaction route is deemed as viable and sustainable [11–14]. There have been many reports about the production of cyclopentanone from hydrogenation of furfural. For example, Gao et al. found that aqueous phase hydrogenative rearrangement of furfural (FAL) to cyclopentanone (CPO) could be achieved over Pd catalysts supported on H-ZSM-5 zeolites [1]. Herrera et al. found that the highest furfural conversion (35%) and cyclopentanone yield (25%) was obtained over carbon nanotube-supported nickel catalyst [2]. FA acts as an intermediate in this reaction and the conversion of FA to CPO is a multiple-step process [15], in which the furan ring of FA is firstly hydrolyzed to open the ring and the sequential hydrogenation as well as dehydration reactions form CPO, as shown in Scheme 1 . One of the key challenges in such a reaction route is the deep hydrogenation of the furan ring in FA to tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol (THFA) [16], which blocks the reaction pathways for the formation of CPO. Copper-based catalysts are reported to be active and selective for the conversion of furfural to FA, inhibiting the successive hydrogenation of FA to form THFA [17–19]. Nonetheless, Cu-based catalysts are prone to agglomeration in aqueous phase that is the reaction medium for conversion of furfural to CPO [20]. In comparison to Cu, Ni species is more resistant to aggregation in water [21]. However, nickel-based catalysts are also generally active for hydrogenation of not only the carbonyl functionality but also furan ring in furfural or FA. This forms THFA and makes the further conversion to CPO impossible. To use nickel catalysts in conversion of furfural to CPO, its excessive activity for hydrogenation of furan ring must be significantly reduced. Various strategies have been reported for adjusting the activity of Ni species. For example, the molten NiSn liquid alloys have been used for catalytic conversion of methane for simultaneous hydrogen and carbon production [22]. NiSn@C heterogeneous catalyst was also developed for synthesizing bio-alcohols [23]. Formation of NiFe alloy in NiFe catalyst was found to decrease the catalytic activity for the hydrogenation of the C=C bond in furan ring, facilitating the conversion of FA to pentanediol [24]. Besides, it is well known that sulfurized Ni-Mo-based catalysts have been successfully used in hydrodesulfurization process [25]. The sulfurization reduces the catalytic activity for hydrogenation of aromatics rings. Herein, the modification of Ni/SiO2 catalyst with NiSO4 was used to tailor the hydrogenation activity of the catalyst. This shows some similarity with sulfurization but owns its unique features. The impregnated NiSO4 could be reduced with hydrogen to form NixSy species, the sulfur in which might also interact with the metallic nickel species originated from the reduction of NiO on the silica carrier. In this way, the activity of Ni/SiO2 catalyst for hydrogenation might be tailored. The conversion of FA to THFA might be suppressed and selective conversion of FA to CPO could thus be possible. Thus, in this study, the hydrogenation of FA to CPO over Ni/SiO2 catalyst modified with various loading of NiSO4 was conducted in aqueous medium to elucidate the impacts of NixSy species on the catalytic activity. Vanillin was also selected as a model compound to assess the change of acidity of the catalyst with the addition of NiSO4 on distribution of the products. The results showed that the introduction of NiSO4 to surface of the Ni/SiO2 catalyst significantly impacted the capability of nickel sites for hydrogenation of C=O and C=C bond in furan ring and the distribution of acidic sites. This further changed the reaction routes in hydrogenation of FA or vanillin. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Chemicals Nickel nitrate [Ni(NO3)2⋅6H2O] (99.9 %) and nickel sulfate (NiSO4, 98.5 %) were purchased from Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Co., Ltd and Damao Chemical Reagent Factory, respectively. FA (99.9 %) was purchased from Aladdin Chemistry Co., Ltd. Cyclopentanone (99.9 %), cyclopentanol (99.9 %), 4-hydroxy-2-cyclopentenone (standard sample), 2-cyclopentenone (standard sample), ethanol, and THFA (99.9 %) were obtained from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. Porous silica was purchased from Qingdao Chengyu Chemical Co., Ltd. All chemicals are of analytical grade and were used directly. 2.2 Catalyst synthesis NiSx/SiO2 (x was equivalent of 0, 2, 6, and 10 wt% loading of NiSO4 to the silica support) catalysts with different Ni and S ratios were synthesized by an incipient wetness impregnation method. The silica support was crushed into fine powder with a pulverizer and then dried in an oven at 100°C for 4 h to remove the moisture adsorbed from air. Ni(NO3)2⋅6H2O was used as Ni source and the loading of Ni was controlled to be 10 wt% to silica. NiSO4 was used as the S source and the loading of NiSO4 was regulated to be 0 wt%, 2 wt%, 6 wt%, and 10 wt% to the silica support, respectively. A mixed aqueous solution, containing Ni(NO3)2⋅6H2O and NiSO4, was used for the impregnation on SiO2. In particular, NiSO4 (10 wt%) was used as Ni source and S source at the same time in S10/SiO2 catalyst. The aqueous solution of NiSO4 was used for impregnation on SiO2. The impregnated samples were dried at room temperature overnight and transferred into an oven at 100°C for 24 h. The catalyst precursors were then calcined in N2 atmosphere at 600°C for 2 h in a N2 flow (60 mL/min), and followed by reduction in a mixed flow of N2 and H2 (60 mL/min of each gas) at 600°C for further hydrogenation experiments. 2.3 Catalytic test The catalytic experiments were carried out in an autoclave reactor made of SS 316 with a stirring speed of 600 rpm and a tunable initial reaction atmosphere. A certain amount of reactants, solvents, and catalysts were loaded into a glass vial with a volume of 10 mL fitted in the autoclave reactor before the heating up. The reactor after assembly was purged with pressurized hydrogen and then heated at a specific reaction temperature. The liquid products and catalyst were collected after finishing the experiments for further analysis. A gas chromatography coupling with a mass spectrometer (GC-MS, Shimadzu GC-MS-QP 2020) was used for the qualitative and quantitative analysis of the liquid products. The detailed instrument parameters and operating procedures followed the previous study [26]. The conversion of reactants and the yield of targeting products were calculated following Eqs. (1) and (2). (1) Conversion ( % ) = Mole of reactant converted Mole of reactant loaded × 100 % (2) Yield ( % ) = Mole of targeting product produced Mole of reactant loaded × 100 % 2.4 Characterizations of the catalysts The Ni-based catalysts were characterized with X-ray diffraction spectrometer (XRD, Rigaku Ultima IV) to probe crystallinity of the metal species with a scanning rate of 20 °/min in the range of 5 to 80°. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM, EM-30 Plus, COXEM) with backscattered electrons as the imaging signal was employed to roughly analyze the distribution of nickel and morphological characteristics of catalyst. The elemental compositions of the catalysts were determined with a scanning electron microscope (FE SEM, JEOL-6300 F, 15 KV) equipped with energy-dispersive X-ray spectrometry (EDS). The morphology and elemental compositions of the nickel catalysts were further analyzed by using the transmission electron microscope (TEM, JEM 2100 plus) fitted with an energy-dispersive X-ray spectrometry. N2 adsorption-desorption was performed to probe pore structure of the calcined samples with the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method with a Biaode SSA-6000 instrument (China). The samples were pretreated at 120°C for 4 h, and then the adsorption-desorption of N2 was measured at 77 K. Temperature programmed reduction in hydrogen (H2-TPR) was carried out to analyze reduction behavior of NiO and NiSO4 with a Vodo VDSorb 91x instrument (China). The distribution of acidic sites was tested by temperature programmed desorption (Biaode PCA-1200 instrument) with NH3 as the probing molecule (NH3-TPD). Before the measurement, the reduced catalysts were firstly pretreated in a helium flow of 30 mL/min before NH3 adsorption, which was then purged for 10 min in helium and then heated to 150°C for 30 min (ramp rate of 20°C/min). Once cooled, the catalysts were flushed in a NH3 flow (50 mL/min) at 50°C for 60 min. After that, helium (flow rate of 30 mL/min) was used to purge NH3 that was physically adsorbed on the catalyst for 30 min. When the baseline was flat, the temperature-programmed desorption started via heating the sample to 750°C with the ramping rate of 20°C/min. The in-situ Diffuse Reflectance Infrared Fourier Transform Spectroscopy for investigating the reaction mediates formed in the hydrogenation was performed by using a Nicolet iS50 spectrometer fitted with a Harrick Praying Mantis DRIFT cell. Before the analysis, the reduced samples were loaded in the in-situ cell, and the reaction substrate was added dropwise. The mixture was then heated to 200°C with a ramping rate of 10°C/min, and the reaction maintained for 20 min in a H2 flow (50 mL/min). The spectra on surface of the catalyst were recorded with an interval of every 7 s. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterizations 3.1.1 X-ray diffraction Fig. 1 shows that the catalysts with the varied loading of NiSO4 displayed different diffraction patterns. The reduced Ni/SiO2 catalyst contained only metallic Ni phase (JCPDS 87-0712), while the NiS10/SiO2 catalyst showed a clear diffraction of Ni3S2 phase (JCPDS 71-1682), in addition to the metallic Ni species. The introduction of NiSO4 to surface of the catalyst formed Ni3S2, which should be resulted from the reduction of NiSO4. Nevertheless, the atomic ratio of Ni to S in NiSO4 is 1 : 1, which was lower than that of 3 : 2 in Ni3S2. Apparently, some sulfur species generated from the reduction of NiSO4 also reacted with the metallic Ni species from the reduction of NiO. Even though the loading of NiSO4 reached 10 wt%, some metallic Ni still co-existed. The diffraction peaks of Ni3S2 in NiS2/SiO2 and NiS6/SiO2 catalysts were insignificant, which was probably due to their higher dispersion and the low loading. Table 1 shows that the crystalline size increased slightly with the loading of NiSO4, which could be due to the higher migration rate of Ni with the presence of S species. 3.1.2 N2 adsorption/desorption Fig. 2 a shows the N2 adsorption-desorption curves of the prepared catalysts and their carrier. Fig. 2b shows the distribution of pore size of the catalysts and their carriers. In comparison with the pore size distribution curve of the adsorption branch, a peak caused by the tensile strength effect appears in the curve of the desorption branch around 3.8 nm, which was a false peak [27], so the adsorption branch was chosen for the plot. The isotherms of all samples were assigned to type IV isotherm with a hysteresis loop of H2-type (Fig. 2b) [28,29], which was predetermined by the structural properties of the silica carrier. The distributed Ni particles and Ni3S2 species occupied pores in the inner or outer surface of the carrier, leading to the reduced specific surface area of the catalyst with the gradual increase of NiSO4 loading (Table 1, Entries 1 to 5). The pore volume decreased as expected, while the pore size of the carrier was not affected much, suggesting the formation of stack pores with the deposition of Ni and Ni3S2 on outer surface of the pores. 3.1.3 Temperature programmed reduction in hydrogen The reducibility of the calcined catalysts was investigated by H2-TPR [30,31], as shown in Fig. 3 a. SiO2 had a weak to milder interaction with NiO, and hence the reduction temperature of NiO in Ni/SiO2 located in the range of 300-550°C. The wide span of the reduction temperature was due to the varied extent of the contact/interact of NiO with the silica carrier. The introduction of NiSO4 weakened the interaction between nickel oxides with silica carrier, as evidenced by the shift of the main reduction temperature to the lower region. This was related to the increased crystalline sizes in the reduced catalysts (Table 1). Additionally, with the increase of loading of NiSO4, the H2 uptake increased remarkably [32]. Obviously, the reduction of NiSO4 consumed some hydrogen (Fig. 3a). The NiSO4 was reduced to NixSy, and it further reacted with the metallic nickel to form the Ni3S2, as measured with the XRD characterization. 3.1.4 Temperature programmed desorption of NH3 The profiles for the desorption of NH3 on the reduced catalysts are shown in Fig. 3b and the abundance of acidic sites was calculated [33]. The overall abundance of acidic sites of Ni/SiO2 was obviously less than that of NiS10/SiO2. The adding of NiSO4 to Ni/SiO2 introduced more Ni and S species, which contributed to the increase of the total number of acid sites in NiS10/SiO2. Especially, the NiS10/SiO2 catalyst had the higher abundance of the acidic sites with either the weak, medium or strong strength. Fig. 3b shows that the desorption spectrum of NH3 extended to the high temperature regions, suggesting the formation of the acidic sites with strong strength. In the conversion of furfural or FA to CPO, acidic sites are required and involved in the dehydration of FA and also the formation of ring structures in CPO. The influence of the acidic sites on the hydrogenation and arrangement of FA will be further discussed. 3.1.5 SEM and elemental mappings SEM images are shown in Fig. 4 . The catalyst retained the original morphology of the SiO2 support, showing an irregular block shape. The yield of backscattered electrons was monotonically increasing with the atomic number of the sample [34]. Comparing to light elements like Si (atomic number 16) and O (atomic number 8), the heavier elements, like Ni (atomic number 28), can stand out as bright spots [34]. From Fig. 4 (a-d), more bright spots appeared and the dispersion of the bright spots was relatively uniform. This originated from the increasing Ni sites with the addition of NiSO4. In addition, the bright spots had light and dark differences, which might be attributed to the metallic nickel and Ni3S2, respectively. The results of elemental mappings in Table 2 also confirmed that S was introduced to the prepared NiSx/SiO2 catalyst, and the abundance of S species increased with the increasing loading of NiSO4. 3.1.6 TEM and elemental mappings Fig. 5 shows the TEM images of NiS10/SiO2 catalyst. Irregular block structure was observed, which was consistent with the SEM image results, reflecting the original morphology of the SiO2 support. The mappings of Ni and S elements over NiS10/SiO2 catalyst are shown in Fig. 5(d-f), indicating that various elements were generally uniformly dispersed on the support. S element was less abundant than Ni element and only sporadically dotted across the carrier (Fig. 5d-f), which was consistent with the results of XRD. The elemental mapping of the catalyst showed that the areas for the concentrated Ni and S species overlapped, which was related to formation of Ni3S2 species. The spacing d of lattice fringes in Fig. 5b was measured to be 2.8994 Å, which was consistent with the spacing of the (110) crystal planes of Ni3S2, further indicating the presence of Ni3S2 in the catalyst. The lattice fringe spacing of 2.0345 Å in Fig. 5c corresponded to the lattice spacing of the (111) facet of Ni, confirming the co-existence of Ni3S2 and metallic nickel species. 3.2 Catalytic activity Through a series of experiments, it was found that the yield of cyclopentanone had an obvious relationship with the acidity and hydrogenation activity of the catalysts. The yield of cyclopentanone over various catalysts, prepared by introducing different amounts of NiSO4 into the Ni-based catalysts, was very different. Under optimal reaction conditions, nearly 70% yield of CPO was obtained over the NiS2/SiO2 and NiS6/SiO2 catalysts, while only 38% yield of CPO was obtained over the NiS10/SiO2 catalyst (Table 6, entry 7 to 9). The reasons for the change of yield were analyzed in detail below. Table 3 shows the distribution of products from the hydrogenation of FA versus the various reaction temperatures. The result of the blank test (Table 3, entry 13) showed that rearrangement of FA with the aid of water took place. The hydrogenation of C=C could not be achieved without the involvement of the hydrogenation sites. In addition, acid catalysts could promote ring opening, rearrangement and dehydroxylation during the formation of cyclopentanone, accelerating rearrangement reactions and the conversion of intermediates. Besides, the imbalance between conversion (100 %) and yield (74%) also showed that FA and/or the derived intermediates easily polymerized in the aqueous phase. Over Ni/SiO2, the absence of sulfur species rendered the formation of THFA as the major product with a yield of 97% (Table 3, entry 1), which was attributed to the high activity of metallic nickel species for hydrogenation of the C=C bond in the furan ring [35]. Over S10/SiO2 and NiS10/SiO2, the major product shifted from THFA to CPO (Table 3, entry 2 and 3), confirming that the hydrogenation of the furan ring in FA was effectively suppressed with the presence of sulfur species. The results in Table 3 also showed the formation of Ni3S2 reduced the capability of the catalyst for the hydrogenation of C=C bond in furan ring. In addition, the increasing reaction temperature from 150 to 170°C did not improve the formation of CPO much, as the polymerization was also promoted. Additionally, the yield of CPO was not high over especially NiS10/SiO2 catalyst (Table 3). This was probably due to the lack of effective coordination between the acidic and hydrogenation sites. The reaction intermediates formed by the ring-opening of FA was not further hydrogenated and dehydrated, but polymerized instead. The abundance and strong acidic sites over NiS10/SiO2 catalyst could catalyze the polymerization of FA and/or the reactive reaction intermediates. Table 4 shows the effects of various concentrations of FA on the formation of CPO. The increase of FA concentration from 1 to 4.0 wt% did increase the production of CPO. The conversion of FA to CPO involves intramolecular rearrangement and thus it has not been clarified about the reason for the increasing yield of CPO with the higher substrate loading. Additionally, the results herein did demonstrate that the addition of 2 or 10 wt% NiSO4 did not make a big difference in terms suppressing the activity for hydrogenation of the furan ring in FA. The presence of a small amount of sulfur could effectively poison the metallic nickel in Ni/SiO2 catalyst, significantly reducing the catalytic activity for hydrogenation of the furan ring in FA. The enhanced abundance of acidic sites on NiS10/SiO2 catalyst with the introduction of NiSO4 might catalyze the polymerization of FA and/or its derived intermediates (Table 5 , entry 7 to 9). This could be one possible reason for the low yields of CPO, which was further investigated via decreasing catalyst loading from 40 to 10 mg to reduce the availability of acidic sites in the reaction medium. Table 5 shows that the yield of CPO increased significantly when the catalyst loading decreased. The decreasing abundance of hydrogenation sites with lower loading of catalyst reduced the chance for excessive hydrogenation. More importantly, the lower amount of acidic sites also helped to suppress the polymerization reactions. Hydrogenation of vanillin versus varied loading of catalyst was also performed at 140°C (Table 6 ). At the catalyst loading of 40 or 30 mg, the increase of the loading of NiSO4 enhanced the production of MMP, the yield of which reached 94.3% over NiS10/SiO2 catalyst with the loading of 30 mg. The production of 4-(ethoxymethyl)-2-methoxyphenol (EMP) was suppressed correspondingly. EMP is an ether produced from etherification of vanillyl alcohol with the ethanol medium. Obviously, the presence of abundant acidic sites in NiS10/SiO2 catalyst helped to remove the hydroxyl group in vanillyl alcohol. The acidic sites might promote the protonation of the hydroxyl group in vanillyl alcohol, facilitating the subsequent hydrogenolysis to form 2-methoxy-4-methylphenol (MMP) (Table 6, entry 4 to 6). Additionally, for the hydrogenation of vanillin, the further lower loading of catalyst would lead to the deficiency of metallic sites for hydrogenation, reducing the conversion of vanillin at 140°C. 3.3 In-situ DRIFTS characterization Fig. 6 shows the in-situ DRIFTS characterization of functional groups of reaction intermediates in the hydrogenation of FA over Ni/SiO2, Ni10S6/SiO2, and NiS10/SiO2 catalysts versus increasing temperature from 40 to 200°C in a hydrogen flow. The absorption peaks at 1620 and 1500 cm−1 belonged to the C=C bond in furan ring of FA [35–37]. The absorption peaks of Ar-H groups (788-881 cm−1) were also observed [38,39]. Stronger adsorption of the C=C bond as well as -C-H bonds in saturate furan ring was observed over Ni/SiO2 catalyst (Fig. 6a) [40], which resulted in the full hydrogenation of the furan ring [41], as evidenced by the high yield of THFA at 97% (Table 3, Entry 1). This could be attributed to the stronger adsorption of furan ring in FA on surface of the catalyst together with the superior activity of the Ni/SiO2 catalyst for hydrogenation of C=C bond. On the contrary, NiS6/SiO2 and NiS10/SiO2 catalysts were not active for the hydrogenation of C=C bond in furan ring. The absorption of -C-H (2870 cm−1 and 2939 cm−1) in alkanes were rather weak (Fig. 6a–c). Over NiS6/SiO2 and NiS10/SiO2 catalysts [35,37], stronger adsorption to the C-O-C (1010 cm−1) groups in furan ring and -OH groups (1280 cm−1) in FA (Fig. 6b and c) was observed [35,36,42], and the formed Ni3S2 species could facilitate the adsorption of oxygen-containing groups in FA but lower the adsorption of furan ring. This also explained the improved yield of CPO over this catalyst (Tables 4 and 5). In addition, the relative ratio of C=C and -OH groups in FA gradually decreased with the increase of NiSO4 introduction, indicating that catalysts containing more Ni3S2 species had stronger adsorption of -OH groups in FA. Furthermore, the reaction intermediates also showed strong adsorption to the C=C bond of the furan ring. It wasthus speculated that the competition between acid catalysis and hydrogenation occurs during the initial stage of the hydrogenation of FA in aqueous phase. The formation of Ni3S2 significantly reduced the hydrogenation activity of Ni, thereby suppressing the deep hydrogenation reaction of furan ring and promoting the formation of CPO via rearrangement reaction. The red-shift of C-O-C and -OH groups in FA over NiS6/SiO2 and NiS10/SiO2 was observed (Fig. 6e-f) [38], which indicated the strong adsorption of C-O-C and -OH groups in FA facilitating the rearrangement of FA in water for the production of CPO. In addition, the red-shift of the -OH bond in water was observed over Ni10/SiO2 catalyst, indicating that the introduction of NiSO4 weakened the interaction between water and Ni-based catalysts, which could further improve the thermal stability of sulfurized Ni-based catalysts. 3.4 Reusability of the catalysts Fig. 7 shows Ni/SiO2 showed a slight decrease in terms of yields of THFA, but the yield generally maintained > 80% after four cycles. The NiS2/SiO2 and NiS6/SiO2 showed the low yields of CPO in the first cycle, while the yield increased in the further cycles. These three nickel catalysts with introduction of NiSO4 were more stable, and no obvious deactivation of catalyst was observed. Fig. 1b and Table 1 show that the crystalline size in NiS10/SiO2 catalysts increased much, and the suitable introduction of S species in NiS2/SiO2 could stabilize crystalline particles well. The acidic sites over the sulfurized catalysts could aid the conversion of FA to CPO, but the polymerization reactions were also promoted [43], which could lower the stability of Ni-based catalysts and result in the sintering of Ni species. A balance of the acidity of catalyst should be achieved for selective conversion of furfural or FA to CPO. 3.5 Limitations and future prospects The results mentioned above demonstrated that introducing NiSO4 into Ni-based catalyst could effectively suppress the catalytic activity of the nickel catalyst for hydrogenation of the furan ring in FA. This makes the conversion of FA to CPO possible. Nevertheless, the conversion of furfural or FA to CPO requires the involvement of hydrogenation. Thus, the catalyst needs to maintain a reasonable hydrogenation activity to achieve the efficient conversion of FA to CPO. The loading of NiSO4 hence needs to be controlled accurately to suppress the activity for hydrogenation of the furan ring but not reduce hydrogenation activity of catalyst much. How to control and achieve the balance needs to be further investigated. Additionally, the introduction of NiSO4 also creates more acidic sites with strong strength, which could also be involved in the conversion of furfural or FA and could particularly catalyze polymerization reactions. How do the acidic sites impact the reaction network in the conversion of furfural or FA also deserves further attention. In addition, herein the sulfur species were introduced via the reduction of NiSO4. Other sulfur source could also be used to modify the nickel catalyst to adjust the activity of Ni species easily. How do the varied types of sulfur sources affect the formation of NixSy species and the catalytic behaviors in varied hydrogenation reactions needs to be further investigated. Meanwhile, the preparation of catalyst with some special function such as hydrogen spillover effects [44], the monoatomic catalysts [45,46] and the catalysts with alloyed metallic sites [47,48] should also be considered for selectivity of the catalyst. 4 Conclusions In summary, sulfur species were introduced to Ni/SiO2 catalyst via loading of NiSO4 to suppress the catalytic activity of the nickel sites for hydrogenation of furan ring in FA, aiming to achieve high selectivity of CPO from FA. The results showed that introduction of NiSO4 to surface of the Ni/SiO2 catalyst formed Ni3S2 via the reaction between NixSy generated from the reduction of NiSO4 and the metallic Ni species. Furthermore, the presence of NiSO4 weakened interaction between nickel oxides and silica carrier, which also significantly enhanced overall abundance of acidic sites, generating some acidic sites with strong strength. Ni3S2 and metallic nickel species co-existed on surface of the catalysts, even in the NiS10/SiO2 catalyst with the loading of NiSO4 as high as 10 wt%. The presence of sulfur species with either the loading of NiSO4 of 2 or 10 wt% could effectively hinder hydrogenation of furan ring in FA, inhibiting formation of THFA over the NiSx/SiO2 catalysts with presence of sulfur species. This shifted the major product from THFA to CPO from the hydrogenation of FA. Formation of Ni3S2 reduced the capability of catalyst for hydrogenation of C=C bonds, even with the presence of a small amount of sulfur on surface of the catalyst. Nevertheless, the enhanced abundance of acidic sites with the introduction of NiSO4 could catalyze the polymerization of FA and/or its derived intermediates, which diminished formation of CPO. Reducing loading of NiS10/SiO2 catalyst decreased availability of acidic sites, suppressing polymerization while enhancing the formation of CPO. However, the introduction of acidic sites in NiS10/SiO2 catalyst helped to remove the hydroxyl group in vanillyl alcohol in hydrogenation of vanillin, facilitating production of 2-methoxy-4-methylphenol as the major product via enhanced hydrogenolysis reaction. The in-situ DRIFTS characterization of hydrogenation of FA over Ni/SiO2 catalyst suggested that the C=C in furan ring of FA could be strongly adsorbed on surface of the catalyst and be hydrogenated. In comparison, the C-O-C and -OH in FA functionalities in FA or derived intermediates could be strongly adsorbed on the NiS10/SiO2 catalysts, facilitating the rearrangement of furan ring but not saturation of the ring structures. The recycle stability tests showed that the Ni/SiO2 and NiS10/SiO2 catalysts could maintain the catalytic activity, but the polymerization reactions catalyzed by the acidic sites introduced with the loading of NiSO4 needs to be further tackled to further enhance the selectivity from the conversion of FA to CPO. coredata.dc:description: Nickel-based catalysts are widely used in hydrogenation of varied types of organics. However, the nickel catalyst, like Ni/SiO2, lacks selectivity for hydrogenation of C=C and C=O. This is undesirable in some scenarios, such as conversion of biomass-derived furfuryl alcohol (FA) to cyclopentanone (CPO), a fine chemical, in which the C=C in furan ring of FA needs to be retained. In this study, introduction of sulfur species to Ni/SiO2 catalyst via loading NiSO4 was adopted to inhibit hydrogenation of furan ring in FA, aiming to achieve conversion of FA to CPO via ring-opening route. The results indicated that NiSO4 was reduced to NixSy, which further reacted with metallic Ni, forming Ni3S2 species and introducing the acidic sites with high-strength. The co-existence of NixSy and metallic Ni species effectively hindered hydrogenation of furan ring in FA, reducing tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol (THFA) yield from 97% over Ni/SiO2 to 0 over the NiSx/SiO2 catalysts and shifting the major product to CPO. Nonetheless, the enhanced acidic sites along with the introduction of NiSO4 catalyzed polymerization of reaction intermediates, competing with the production of CPO. The acidic sites, however, facilitated hydrogenolysis of vanillyl alcohol to selectively produce (yield: 94.3%) in hydrogenation of vanillin. Characterization of hydrogenation of FA with in-situ Diffuse Reflectance Infrared Fourier Transform Spectroscopy (DRIFTS) technique suggested the oxygen-containing functionalities in FA, instead of furan ring, could strongly adsorb on the NiS10/SiO2 catalyst, enhancing rearrangement reaction to form CPO while suppressing hydrogenation of the furan ring.
coredata.dc:title: Introduction of NiSO4 to Ni/SiO2 catalyst in hydrogenation of furfuryl alcohol: Tailoring metallic nickel sites to switch major product from tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol to cyclopentanone
